title: Segment fault when executing a script module in C++
body_html:
🐛 Bug

To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

  1. I followed the instruction from the web page https://pytorch.org/tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html#step-4-executing-the-script-module-in-c.
  2. I used the same way described in the instruction to produce my own model.pt, and that works well -- I got a model.pt.
  3. The cmake and make steps also works .And the model assertion returned OK.
  4. But when It comes to STEP 4: EXECUTING THE SCRIPT MODULE IN C++, I got a segment fault.
  5. Then I got an opinion -- "Maybe there is something wrong with my model or my input tensor. Let's try out the official example!" . But ,I got the same answer--segment fault...

Expected behavior

Environment

Please copy and paste the output from our
environment collection script
(or fill out the checklist below manually).

You can get the script and run it with:

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pytorch/pytorch/master/torch/utils/collect_env.py
# For security purposes, please check the contents of collect_env.py before running it.
python collect_env.py
  • PyTorch Version (e.g., 1.0): 1.0
  • OS (e.g., Linux):centos 7.4.1708
  • How you installed PyTorch (conda, pip, source):conda
  • Build command you used (if compiling from source):
  • Python version:3.7
  • CUDA/cuDNN version:CUDA 9.0 cuDNNv 7.0.5
  • GPU models and configuration:
  • Any other relevant information:

Additional context

body:
## 🐛 Bug

<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->

## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

0. I followed the instruction from the web page https://pytorch.org/tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html#step-4-executing-the-script-module-in-c.
1. I used the same way described in the instruction to produce my own *model.pt*, and that works well -- I got a model.pt. 
1. The cmake  and make steps also works .And the model assertion returned *OK*.
1. But  when It comes to **STEP 4: EXECUTING THE SCRIPT MODULE IN C++**, I got a **segment fault**.
1. Then I got an opinion -- "Maybe there is something wrong with my model or my input tensor. Let's try out the official example!" . But ,I got the same answer--**segment fault**...  

<!-- If you have a code sample, error messages, stack traces, please provide it here as well -->

## Expected behavior

<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->

## Environment

Please copy and paste the output from our
[environment collection script](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pytorch/pytorch/master/torch/utils/collect_env.py)
(or fill out the checklist below manually).

You can get the script and run it with:
```
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pytorch/pytorch/master/torch/utils/collect_env.py
# For security purposes, please check the contents of collect_env.py before running it.
python collect_env.py
```

 - PyTorch Version (e.g., 1.0): **1.0**
 - OS (e.g., Linux):**centos 7.4.1708**
 - How you installed PyTorch (`conda`, `pip`, source):**conda**
 - Build command you used (if compiling from source):
 - Python version:**3.7**
 - CUDA/cuDNN version:**CUDA 9.0 cuDNNv 7.0.5**
 - GPU models and configuration:
 - Any other relevant information:

## Additional context

<!-- Add any other context about the problem here. -->
